item.title: QM
item.description: A week in MSE 570 This page is a trial for exporting notes between Notion and OneNote. I’m still figuring out which one will work best for me. Introduction to QM Class: MSE 570 Reviewed: No Type: Study Notes Week: 37- 2020 A little bit of history The main inconvenience with the classical view of the atom, the Rutherford model, was that it was known already that a particle accelerating in an EM field would eradiate its energy.

item.title: Bonding and forces
item.description: Bonding & Bonding Forces and Energy Atomic bonding (force and energy diagram) Bonding Forces and Energies The net force (FN) between 2 atoms is just the sum of the attractive (FA) and repulsive (FR) force: FN = FA + FR The magnitude of each depends on the separation or interatomic distance (r). The origin of an attractive force FA depends on the particular type of bonding that exists between the two atoms.

item.title: Crystallography
item.description: Crystallography BOOK: Introduction to Crystallography, Sands (1975); Crystallography and the World of Symmetry, Chatterjee (2008) Crystal Structures Crystallography is the study of the structure and properties of the crystalline state. A crystalline material is one in which the atoms are situated in a repeating array over large atomic distances. Two characteristics: long-range order and periodicity. An amorphous material lacks long-range order. Crystalline structures are described though the hard-sphere model, where atoms are thought of being solid spheres with well-defined diameters.

item.title: material properties
item.description: Material Properties Room Temperature Density Room Temperature Stiffness Room Temperature Strengths Room Temperature Resistance to Fracture Room Temperature Electrical Conductivity Modulus of Elasticity (Stiffness) vs. Density

item.title: Module 1 and 2
item.description: Module 1 & 2 - Material Sciences, QM & Periodic Table Lecture 1 - Material Sciences What is ‘material’? Multi-scale structure like bones, are they materials? Aluminum the history of the origin of the material is very imprinted all over the material. Even simple materials consist of countless structural features at different length scales that have enormous Material and Structure 10 microns to atoms = realm of the material science.

item.title: Module 3
item.description: Module 3 - Bonding & Interatomic Potential Lecture 1 Notes - Bonding and hybridization Ionic Bonding Charge transfer between high and low electronegativity atoms in solids +/- charged ions Need at least two different elements Very strong bonding High melting point Increasing R means weaker ionic bond, since centers of charge farther apart. Increasing charge for a given R greatly increases strength of bond Covalent Bonding We have electrons sharing one another We are dealing with valence electrons Directionality - electron density aggregated between the two atoms that are bonding together.

item.title: Module 4
item.description: Module 4 - Crystallography Lecture 1 - Foundations of Crystallography, Symmetric Operations Basic Definitions What would be the difference between the unite cell and the basis/ motif? Symmetry operations Symmetry - formal mathematical description of order. Crystallography - includes ideas of symmetry and the notations used solid-state physics and material sciences. Diffraction - experimental approach of crystallography. Crystal structures - Defining features: long-range order and periodicity.

item.title: Module 5
item.description: Module 5 - Crystals Lecture 1 - Physical Crystal I Metallic Crystal Structures Tend to be densely packed and have the simplest crystal structures. The reasons for this are: Typically are only composed of one element present, or they have similar sizes. Metallic bonding is non-directional Nearest neighbor distances tend to be small in order to lower the bond energy. Electron cloud shields the ‘metallic cores’ from each other. Simple Cubic Structure (SC) Coordination number number 6 (nearest neighbors Octahedral Symmetry, each atom belong to 8 unit cells (therefore each contributes 1/8) Primitive unit cell Atomic Packing Factor APF how much materials vs.

item.title: Module 6
item.description: Module 6 Lecture 1: A few last diffraction considerations Diffraction occurs when interference from the N scattering sites is constructive at the detector To determine if this occurs, we need to add the contributions of all N scatterers: If you look in the real crystal and you could identify the locations of all these atoms in the crystals is the Râ±¼ and the Fourier Transform for all the atoms will give you the reciprocal lattice of that crystal.

item.title: MS
item.description: Introduction to Material Science SUMMARY: Materials and Material Sciences Recall Definitions The Material Paradigm Classification of materials Top- Down and Bottom- Up Science Notes Material science involves investigating the relationship that exists between the structures and the properties of materials. Material engineering involves, on the bases of these structure, property correlations, designing or engineering the structure of a material to produce a predetermined set of properties. The structure of a material relates to the arrangement of its internal components.

item.title: PT
item.description: The Periodic Table SUMMARY: The Periodic Table and its Properties Recall Notes Aufbau Principle and implications for chemical behavior Valence electrons are going to influence bonding and how the element interacts with other elements. The case of the carbon In general, the electronic configuration is going to be 1sÂ² 2sÂ² spÂ². However, since 2s and 2p are very close in energy 1sÂ² 2sÂ¹ 2pÂ³ can also occur. This hybridized orbital (sp3) can accept up to four bonds Valence Shell for Transition Metals Trends in the Periodic Table
